body: Weird, I don't think we've ever seen that error before. You mentioned your work has new policies - do you know any details about those policies?

Well, I dont know what exactly they could change, but I know that I dont have admin privileges, cant visit gaming sites, usually face some problem with certificates (pip updates), no access to change Program files
Hmm, none of those sound like they should interfere with ZMQ.

@takluyver I can run any test you want. I just have no clue that to do.

PS For example manually running python in cmd.exe works well. This is why I think problem is related with ipython

Yeah, the error message you're getting comes from ZMQ, which is something IPython uses:

```
Assertion failed: Socket is not connected (bundled\zeromq\src\tcp_connecter.cpp:326)
```

@minrk is probably the best person to help debug that.

I haven't seen this exact error, but there's some hope because there have been pyzmq releases since 15.2. Can you try `conda install pyzmq`, which should upgrade to pyzmq 15.4?

Nope, the same problem.
upgraded:

```
 conda:     4.1.6-py27_0  --> 4.1.11-py27_1 conda-forge
 conda-env: 2.5.1-py27_0  --> 2.5.2-py27_0  conda-forge
 pyzmq:     15.2.0-py27_0 --> 15.4.0-py27_0 conda-forge
```

Curious. Does it work in a Python 3 env?

```
conda create -n test-py3 python=3 notebook
activate test-py3
jupyter notebook
```

I wonder if some security policy is preventing the TCP connections? It's a bit troubling that even Googling for the error turns up nothing, so hitting WSAENOTCONN seems to be pretty rare.

You might also try running the pyzmq test suite:

```
conda install pytest
py.test -v --pyargs zmq
```

1) python3 environment gives the same error. (first block)
2) I believe there is some restriction with TCP connection, for example I can't connect or use  something like teamviewer or remote desktop, connect gaming sites, but I could use t= 
3) Second block finally failed with python crash. Seems to failed on the last line:

```
AppData/Local/Continuum/Anaconda2/lib/site-packages/zmq/tests/test_ioloop.py::Te
stIOLoop::test_poller_events
```

I wonder if it's possible to block anything trying to connect to a port outside a whitelist, even on loopback.

(Jupyter talks to kernels using several network sockets, but by default it listens on the 'loopback' interface, which just lets the computer talk to itself. Security doesn't usually interfere with localhost, thought we have had some overzealous security systems in the past interfering with it in other contexts.)
@takluyver  Guess who's to blame?  Kaspersky antivirus, solution add folder to exception
That's annoying. Thanks for reporting back on what you found!
